metadata.titleEn: Antarctic Ice Sheet Surface Melt 0.05˚ Daily Data Set (1985-1986, 2000-2001, 2015-2016)
metadata.description: Snow, ice, and glaciers have the highest albedo of any part of Earth's surface. The increase in melting of the polar ice sheet results in a rapid and sequential decrease in albedo and subsequently influences the global energy balance. The hydrological system derived from surface melt and basal meltwater will affect the dynamic stability of ice sheet and therefore mass balance. The dataset combined microwave radiometer product and optical albedo product, the daily, winter (June-August) averages and July averages of the former are used for layer-stacking, then Gram-Schmidt Spectral Sharpening was adapted to fuse the layer-stacking results with MODIS GLASS albedo product. The spatial resolution of fusion-results has been downscaled from 25 km to 0.05˚. By employing a threshold-based melt detection approach for each fusion-results pixel, Antarctic ice sheet surface melt daily product for 1985-1986, 2000-2001, 2015-2016 (DSSMIS) was generated. The spatial resolution of DSSMIS is higher than that of published data sets at home and abroad. Combined with the advantages of radiometer and albedo data, the spatial details characteristics are enhanced and consistent with the extraction range of the original radiometer products, effectively reducing the noise of the radiometer. It better reflects the melting gradient of mountainous area, groundline area and ice shelf over time, DSSMIS has a higher accuracy. DSSMIS’s data type is integer, where 1 is melted, 0 is not melted, 255 is masked area besides Antarctic ice sheet, and the data set is stored as *.nc.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the surface melting data is stored in NC format. The file name is "antarcticcdailysurfacemeltyyyy-yyyy. NC", where yyyy-yyyy represents the year. For example, ‘antarcticcdailysurfacemelt1985-1986.nc’ represents the NC file, which describes the surface melting range of the Antarctic ice sheet from July 1, 1985 to June 30, 1986. The NC file contains four variables: melt and polar_ Stereographic, x and y, respectively represent the melting pixel value, coordinate system information, X coordinate and Y coordinate in the projection coordinate system.

Data reading method: all NC files in the dataset can be directly read by panoply program （https://www.giss.nasa.gov/tools/panoply/download/ ）, select the variable melt , create the XY coordinate axis corresponding to the variable x and variable y for browsing, and change the time to browse the melting range of different dates. If you want to save it as a separate picture for display or analysis, you can use the "multidimensional tool - create NetCDF grid layer" tool in ArcGIS program to process the results and generate a file in TIF format, including the melting range of all days in the corresponding year. You can change the display time by opening "enable time in this layer" in the "attribute - time" tab. In addition, you can also select GDAL, NCO, CDO and other tools to open NC files or convert them to other formats.

background: The melting of the Antarctic ice sheet surface is a sensitive factor in global climate change, significantly impacting the material and energy balance of the Antarctic ice sheet. As global temperatures rise, the runoff generated by the melting of the Antarctic ice sheet is a major source of uncertainty in predicting future climate and sea level changes. Therefore, further deepening our understanding of Antarctic ice sheet melting is of great significance. Currently, the frozen-thaw products of the Antarctic ice sheet released by domestic and international sources are mostly derived from microwave radiometer data, which has a relatively low spatial resolution (25 km). Additionally, using a single sensor to detect ice sheet surface melting under different conditions (latitude, altitude, terrain, etc.) has its limitations. Microwave scatterometers are more sensitive to liquid water in the snowpack than microwave radiometers; microwave radiometers perform best in areas with intense melting; model data, which takes terrain factors into account, can provide a good supplement in mountainous regions where satellite remote sensing is difficult to operate.
challenges: Due to the extreme scarcity of observational data on liquid water in the snow layer of the polar regions, and the fact that these data are often not continuous.
methods: This dataset utilizes microwave radiometer, microwave scatterometer, and regional climate model data to obtain freeze-thaw time series from each data source based on a threshold method. After registration, the Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method is employed for fusion, resulting in a freeze-thaw product for the Antarctic ice sheet from 1999 to 2019. First, the freeze-thaw time series from each data source is obtained using the threshold method, and after registration, the CTC method is used to evaluate relative accuracy and fuse the products. The threshold method identifies change points in the microwave radiometer brightness temperature (Tb) and microwave scatterometer backscatter (σ0). When the microwave brightness temperature or backscatter exceeds or falls below the winter average by a certain threshold, it is determined to be a melting signal. After registering the products from different data sources, CTC obtains their relative accuracy by decomposing the 3×3 covariance matrix of the three sets of ice sheet surface melting monitoring products.
dataset: The dataset uses the SSM/I sensor mounted on the DMSP (Defense Meteorological Satellite Program) satellites. The South Hemisphere SSM/I Level-3 EASE-Grid brightness temperature product used in this dataset covers the time range from 1999 to 2019, with a spatial resolution of 25 km and a temporal resolution of daily. The scatterometer used in this dataset is the C-band ASCAT (Advanced Scatterometer). The dataset employs the daily backscatter product of SIR (Scatterometer Image Reconstruction) with a spatial resolution of 4.45 km for studying surface melting of the Antarctic ice sheet from 1999 to 2019. The liquid water content output product from the RACMO2 model has a spatial resolution of 27.5 km and a time range from 1999 to 2019. The Antarctic ice sheet melt dataset contains two subsets: "Melt1999_2009.nc" and "Melt2010_2019.nc." The dataset naming follows the format "theme + location + time," while the subset naming follows the format "theme + time." The two subsets store Antarctic ice sheet melt data for the periods of 1999-2009 and 2010-2019, respectively.
findings: In summary, by integrating data from microwave radiometers, microwave scatterometers, and regional climate models, a high spatial and temporal resolution dataset of freeze-thaw conditions on the Antarctic ice sheet has been obtained. The dataset has been validated against temperature data from scientific observation stations and demonstrates good accuracy. This dataset is of great significance for studying the distribution and development process of surface melting on the Antarctic ice sheet and understanding its impact on the mass balance of the ice sheet.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using single-sensor data for detecting surface melting of ice sheets, and how might multi-sensor approaches address this challenge?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the limitation of detecting ice sheet surface melting under varying conditions such as latitude, altitude, and terrain when using single-sensor data. Multi-sensor approaches, such as combining microwave radiometer and scatterometer data, can enhance sensitivity to surface changes and improve accuracy by leveraging the strengths of each sensor type.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a method used to determine the onset of melting signals from satellite observation data of Antarctic ice sheets?
Example.Answer: An example method involves using a threshold approach to identify sudden changes in microwave brightness temperature (Tb) and backscatter (σ0), where melting is indicated by values exceeding or dropping below the winter mean by a set threshold, followed by fusion using Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) to assess relative accuracy.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with using microwave radiometer data for detecting Antarctic ice sheet surface melting?
Definition.Answer: The challenges associated with using microwave radiometer data for detecting Antarctic ice sheet surface melting include the relatively low spatial resolution of the data (25 km) and the limitations of using a single sensor to detect surface melting under varying conditions such as latitude, altitude, and terrain. Additionally, the scarcity and discontinuity of observation data for liquid water in polar snow layers also pose significant challenges.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method' mean in the context of Antarctic ice sheet melt monitoring?
Definition.Answer: In the context of Antarctic ice sheet melt monitoring, the 'Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method' refers to a technique used to evaluate the relative accuracy of different freeze-thaw time series products derived from microwave radiometer, microwave scatterometer, and regional climate model data. It involves aligning the products and decomposing the covariance matrix of three melt monitoring products to assess their relative precision and create a more accurate merged dataset.

Comparison.Question: What are the key differences between using the Gram-Schmidt method for data fusion and the Categorical Triple Collocation method in creating high-resolution datasets for Antarctic ice sheet melting analysis?
Comparison.Answer: The Gram-Schmidt method enhances spatial resolution by fusing microwave radiometer data with optical albedo products, improving detail clarity. In contrast, the Categorical Triple Collocation method evaluates relative accuracy and fuses products from multiple data sources, providing a high-resolution dataset by decomposing covariance matrices.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the refinement of spatial resolution in datasets impact the interpretation of energy balance and hydrological systems on the Antarctic ice sheet?
Interpretation.Answer: Refining the spatial resolution of datasets can significantly impact the interpretation of energy balance and hydrological systems on the Antarctic ice sheet by providing clearer spatial detail and more accurately capturing the gradient evolution of melting areas. Higher resolution datasets highlight the response of radiometer and albedo data to surface melting, effectively suppressing noise and better reflecting the extent of melting in mountainous, grounding line regions, and ice shelves over time. This improved detail aids in understanding the influence of melting on the ice sheet's material balance and the broader regional energy balance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the necessity of improving spatial resolution in data collection methods for Antarctic ice sheet melting observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need to improve spatial resolution arises from the limitations of traditional data products, which typically have a spatial resolution of 25 km. These limitations can obscure detailed spatial features and the dynamic range of the radiometer products, thereby affecting the accuracy of melt monitoring, especially in areas like mountainous regions, grounding lines, and ice shelves.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a reliance on combining multiple sensor data and modeling approaches to observe Antarctic ice sheet melting?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Combining multiple sensor data and modeling approaches is necessary due to the limitations of using a single sensor under varying conditions such as latitude, altitude, and terrain, which can limit the accuracy of detecting ice sheet surface melting. Additionally, different sensors have unique sensitivities, with microwave scatterometers being more sensitive to liquid water in snow layers compared to radiometers, and regional climate models providing valuable supplementary data for areas where satellite remote sensing is challenging.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges in data availability and continuity influence the development of Antarctic ice sheet melt datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges include the scarcity and non-continuous nature of observational data for liquid water in polar snow layers. These challenges necessitate the use of threshold methods and advanced fusion techniques like Categorical Triple Collocation to enhance the relative accuracy and continuity of melt datasets derived from diverse data sources such as microwave radiometers, scatterometers, and regional climate models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a fusion approach with Gram-Schmidt method to integrate microwave radiometer data and MODIS GLASS albedo products on the spatial resolution of ice melt detection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The consequence of using the Gram-Schmidt method to integrate these data sources is an improvement in spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚. This allows for clearer spatial detail and better reflection of the melting range over mountainous areas, grounding lines, and ice shelves.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the involvement of microwave radiometers and scatterometers in data collection impact the ability to detect the presence of liquid water in polar snow layers?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Microwave scatterometers are more sensitive to liquid water than radiometers, which perform best in areas with intense melting. Using both types of sensors can provide complementary data that address the limitations of single-sensor approaches, particularly under varying conditions like latitude, elevation, and terrain.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the effect of employing the Categorical Triple Collocation method for merging different data sources on the temporal and spatial resolution of Antarctic ice sheet freeze-thaw products?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing the Categorical Triple Collocation method results in a high spatial and temporal resolution freeze-thaw dataset, with improved accuracy validated against temperature data from scientific stations. This approach effectively combines data from multiple sources, enhancing the dataset's reliability and detail.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of integrating microwave radiometer and MODIS GLASS albedo products in the creation of a high-resolution Antarctic ice sheet surface melt dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration aims to enhance the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚, thus providing clearer spatial details and reducing noise, which allows for a more accurate reflection of the gradient evolution of melt areas over time, especially in mountainous, grounding line, and ice shelf regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to consider the specific characteristics of microwave radiometers and scatterometers when developing datasets for monitoring Antarctic ice sheet melt?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Considering these characteristics is crucial because microwave radiometers are effective in areas with intense melting, while scatterometers are more sensitive to liquid water in snow layers. This consideration helps to capture different aspects of melt dynamics under varying conditions such as latitude, altitude, and topography.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using the Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method in the fusion of various data sources for Antarctic ice sheet freeze-thaw products?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to evaluate relative precision and integrate products from microwave radiometers, scatterometers, and regional climate model data by decomposing the covariance matrix of three monitoring products, thereby achieving a high spatial and temporal resolution dataset with verified accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in integrating microwave radiometer data and optical albedo products to improve spatial resolution for studying Antarctic ice sheet surface melting?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration process involves synthesizing microwave radiometer bands using the Gram-Schmidt method to combine them with MODIS GLASS albedo products. This fusion enhances the spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚. The threshold method is then applied to extract surface melting, based on the difference between daily and winter brightness temperatures from microwave radiometer data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method used to evaluate and merge different data sources for Antarctic ice sheet freeze-thaw products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The CTC method is used after obtaining freeze-thaw time series from various data sources through threshold methods. These include microwave radiometer brightness temperatures, microwave scatterometer backscatter, and regional climate model data. The products are aligned, and the CTC method decomposes the 3×3 covariance matrix of the three monitoring products to assess their relative accuracy, allowing for fusion into a comprehensive product.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered in collecting and using liquid water data from polar snow layers, and how are these addressed in data collection for Antarctic ice sheet melt studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational data for liquid water in polar snow layers is extremely rare and often discontinuous, posing a challenge. To address this, multiple data sources such as microwave radiometers, scatterometers, and regional climate models are used. These sources provide complementary insights, with scatterometers offering sensitivity to liquid water, radiometers performing well in high melt areas, and models supplementing where remote sensing is limited.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the integration of multiple data sources to improve spatial resolution in monitoring ice sheet surface melting?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple data sources, such as microwave radiometer data and MODIS GLASS albedo products, is enabled through techniques like Gram-Schmidt spectral sharpening, which improves spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚.

Enablement.Question: How do different sensors contribute to the detection of ice sheet surface melting under varied environmental conditions?
Enablement.Answer: Microwave radiometers are effective in detecting melting in intense melt regions, while microwave scatterometers are more sensitive to liquid water content in snow layers. Regional climate models supplement these datasets, especially in mountainous areas where satellite remote sensing is less effective.

Enablement.Question: What factors enable the accurate extraction of freeze-thaw cycles from satellite data to study Antarctic ice sheet melting?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate extraction of freeze-thaw cycles is enabled by using threshold methods to identify changes in brightness temperature (Tb) and backscatter (σ0) from microwave radiometer and scatterometer data, respectively, and by using Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) to assess relative accuracy and merge products.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset based solely on microwave radiometer data not meet expectations for capturing surface melt variations across different Antarctic regions?
Expectation.Answer: A dataset relying solely on microwave radiometer data might not effectively capture surface melt variations due to the inherent limitations of using a single sensor. The microwave radiometer performs best in areas of intense melting but has limitations when detecting melt under varying conditions such as latitude, altitude, and terrain. Additionally, microwave radiometer data typically has a lower spatial resolution, which may not adequately reflect the detailed variations across different regions of Antarctica.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in achieving high spatial resolution for datasets monitoring Antarctic ice sheet surface melting?
Expectation.Answer: Achieving high spatial resolution for datasets monitoring Antarctic ice sheet surface melting involves challenges such as integrating data from different sources with varying resolutions and sensitivities. Microwave radiometers and scatterometers have different capabilities in detecting surface melt, and the spatial resolution of these instruments is often limited. The integration process, such as using the Gram-Schmidt method for data fusion, aims to enhance resolution but must also address noise suppression and maintain dynamic range, which can be technically complex.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected outcomes from a Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method be significant for enhancing the accuracy of Antarctic ice sheet melt datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method is expected to significantly enhance the accuracy of Antarctic ice sheet melt datasets by evaluating and integrating multiple data sources to determine relative precision. This method allows for a comprehensive understanding of the uncertainties and variabilities present in different datasets such as microwave radiometer, scatterometer, and climate model outputs. By decomposing the covariance matrices of these datasets, CTC provides a robust analysis framework that helps in creating a more reliable and precise melt product, crucial for understanding the melt distribution and progression.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using microwave radiometer and scatterometer data fusion techniques in improving the spatial resolution of Antarctic ice sheet melt datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The fusion of microwave radiometer and scatterometer data is highly effective as it improves spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚ and provides a clearer depiction of melt patterns, particularly in complex terrains like mountain areas and grounding lines. This method leverages the strengths of each sensor type, allowing for enhanced sensitivity to surface melt and better accuracy in reflecting temporal gradients.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges researchers face when using threshold methods for identifying melt signals in polar regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges involve the scarcity and discontinuity of liquid water observation data in polar regions, which complicate the threshold setting process. Additionally, different environmental conditions such as latitude, altitude, and terrain may affect sensor performance, leading to potential limitations in accurately detecting melt signals.

Judgmental.Question: What considerations should be taken into account when designing a data collection strategy to ensure high precision in Antarctic ice sheet melt observations using satellite data?
Judgmental.Answer: A data collection strategy should consider integrating multiple data sources, such as radiometers, scatterometers, and regional climate models, to cover different sensitivities to melt conditions. Calibration and validation with in-situ temperature data from scientific stations are also crucial for maintaining high precision. Additionally, employing advanced data fusion techniques, like the Categorical Triple Collocation method, helps in achieving a more comprehensive and precise melt product.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively address the challenges associated with observing liquid water in polar snow layers.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges associated with observing liquid water in polar snow layers are addressed by utilizing multiple data sources like microwave radiometers and scatterometers, as well as regional climate models. These methods help in capturing the freeze-thaw cycles by detecting changes in microwave brightness temperature and backscatter, which are then fused using techniques like Categorical Triple Collocation to improve the accuracy and resolution of the datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for enhancing the spatial resolution of Antarctic ice sheet surface melting datasets, considering the integration of different data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: Enhancing the spatial resolution of Antarctic ice sheet surface melting datasets can be achieved by integrating microwave radiometer data with optical albedo products, using a fusion method such as the Gram-Schmidt technique. This approach synthesizes microwave radiometer band data with MODIS GLASS albedo products, improving spatial resolution from 25 km to 0.05˚. The method effectively suppresses radiometer noise and reflects the melting area gradient evolution in mountain and grounding line regions more clearly, providing a higher precision product. The integration of multiple data sources, such as microwave scatterometer data and regional climate model outputs, can further refine the dataset by leveraging their respective strengths in different conditions and enhancing the accuracy of the melting signal detection.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest strategies for addressing the challenge of scarce and discontinuous observational data in polar regions when researching Antarctic ice sheet melting.
Request/Directive.Answer: To address the challenge of scarce and discontinuous observational data in polar regions, researchers can employ a combination of satellite data from multiple sensors, such as microwave radiometers and scatterometers, alongside regional climate model outputs. The use of threshold methods to detect melt signals from radiometer brightness temperatures and scatterometer backscatter data can help identify freeze-thaw events. Following data alignment, the Categorical Triple Collocation (CTC) method allows for the fusion of multiple data sources, evaluating relative accuracy and thus compensating for the lack of continuous observations. Incorporating model data that account for terrain and other environmental factors can also supplement gaps in satellite data, providing comprehensive coverage and improving the reliability of the melting dataset.
